subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quickscript for American English
msgSnippet: I think from looking at the Quickscript manual, charater #30 looks like it would be used for the words you list below. Charater #30 s Key Word is A-t and the
messageBody:
I think from looking at the Quickscript manual,
charater #30 looks like it would be used for the words
you list below. Charater #30's Key Word is A-t and the
manual give it being used in the word, "as".

At least to my way of saying things "as", "at" & "and"
all have the same "a" sound.

Chuck

--- kyudosha <kyudosha@...> wrote:
> I've noticed an interesting thing about the Read
> Alphabet (from an
> American perspective). Numbers 31 and 32 (and to an
> extent 34) are
> differentiated as separate sounds, yet are
> pronounced the same by
> American English speakers. While I understand that
> the unused
> letters can simply be omitted, there remain two
> questions:
>
> 1) Which letter is the one to be used for this sound
> as an American
> writing in Quikscript?
>
> 2) Can one of the unused letters be used to
> represent the (distinctly
> American?) vowel represented in the IPA alphabet as:
> "�"? This
> sound
> would be used in such words as "Canada" and "Andy",
> not to mention
> the all-important "and". Has this already been
> suggested, and if so,
> what is the accepted standard for this?
>
> AJW
>
>

I think from looking at the Quickscript manual,
charater #30 looks like it would be used for the words
you list below. Charater #30's Key Word is A-t and the
manual give it being used in the word, "as".

At least to my way of saying things "as", "at" & "and"
all have the same "a" sound.

Chuck
